intro: Ageratina oppositifolia, commonly known as the opposite-leaf ageratum, is a flowering plant native to Central and South America. It is characterized by its opposite leaf arrangement and small, fluffy blue or purple flower heads that resemble cotton balls. The plant belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is known for its aromatic foliage. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in shaded to partially shaded environments. Ageratina oppositifolia is popular in horticulture for its ornamental value and ability to attract pollinators.
